results.title: Aquarium wonderland
results.brief_description: In microscopic and unusual close-up scenes and animation, we see how fish breathe, hear, feel, smell and swim. A boy shows how to set up and maintain an aquarium, using the proper amount of water, plants and food for the goldfish and other animal life it contains.

results.title: Aquarium
results.brief_description: Brilliantly photographed non-narrated tableau of unusual underwater creatures including fish that walk on their ‘hands’, sea horses and octopus. Explores the feeding habits and methods of locomotion of these marine life forms. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Aptitudes and occupations: an introduction to vocational guidance
results.brief_description: Discusses six of the fundamental human aptitudes: social, mechanical, clerical, musical, artistic and scholastic; and indicates how a student may, with the help of an educational or vocational counsellor, determine in which of these aptitudes they are most gifted. Indicates the broad fields of employment in which certain combinations of abilities are required. Narrated by Vincent Pelletier.

results.title: Apt 3 (K)
results.creator_credit: Weston Woods Studios and Morton Schindel
results.brief_description: Wistful harmonica music drifting from an unknown apartment leads Sam and his little brother Ben on a search for its origin. Their discovery provides them with an insight beyond vision and a sense of beauty in the midst of gloom. Subtle tones of greys, greens and purples and the accompanying harmonica score enhance this poignant film. Based on the book by Ezra Jack Keats. Narrated by Charles Turner, music by Sugar Blue.

results.title: Apron strings and atom bombs
results.brief_description: The 50’s were a difficult political time in Australia, mostly due to the Cold War and sense of fear it generated within the community with suspicion directed at Unionists and Communists particularly. It was in this political climate of intolerance that the Union of Australian Women (UAW) was born. Set up primarily to address justice, equal rights and peace, the group were instrumental in specifically targeting: the women’s right to vote; equal pay for equal work; the right to abortion; the right of women to have child care and the fight against conscription. This documentary gathers a group of the founding members of the UAW who share some amusing anecdotes and knowledge that make this oral history a pertinent study of Australia during a politically volatile period.

results.title: April 2nd, 1993
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Silver casts her female gaze onto a series of anonymous male subjects that she follows through the streets of the Marais district in Paris. The resulting `surveillance narrative,’ which features the music of Jo Privat, is an observation of viewing, power, and privacy in a public space.

results.title: April = Aprile
results.creator_credit: Sacher Film, Bac Films (France), Nanni Moretti and Angelo Barbagallo
results.brief_description: Nanni Moretti prefers a personal approach to filmmaking and incorporates part biography and intuition to inform his style. Using mostly untrained and non-professional actors (his real-life wife, son and mother play as themselves), Moretti captures an innocence and infectious quality in his actors. In Aprile, Moretti is a filmmaker keen to document the upcoming national elections in a way that he can say what he feels, whilst not pandering to any polical party. To complicate things his wife is due to give birth to their first child on the night of the elections. The filmmaking process becomes more entwined with Moretti’s notions of raising a family. The chaos of raising the child then serves as a metaphor for creative process and as we watch this develop throughout the film we experience the maturation of the filmmakers vision. Often touted as the Woody Allen of Italy, Moretti’s similar style of storytelling, with his (sometimes) vague and philosophical musings, enable a rare glimpse into the ‘local’ spirit of contemporary Italy. In Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: Approximately panther
results.creator_credit: Artransa Park Studios and Peter Lamb
results.brief_description: Douglas Panther reports on the teenage cults of today. The swing from America to Britain as the current trend-setter in fashion and pop music, originating with The Beatles, is evident. Introduces Australian personalities, Lyn Randell, The Loved Ones, and Normie Rowe who have made the international Scene. Shows several discotheques and comments on the entertainment they offer.

results.title: Approaching poetry in English literature
results.creator_credit: Television Production Unit, Box Hill College of TAFE, Daryl Wayland and David Zweck
results.brief_description: Dr Ray Misson of Melbourne College of Advanced Education seeks to demystify poetry by providing a guide for students to help their approach to this area of literature. In a practical commonsense manner, he uses poems by Donne, Browning, Marvell and Coleridge as examples.

results.title: Approach to sculpture
results.brief_description: The basis of sculptural expression, examples of different forms, and the work of Clement Meadmore. The use of lines, planes and shapes is demonstrated with models and exemplified in the work of modern and classic sculptors. The basic qualities of sculpture. Clement Meadmore working from a model to a full-scale finished sculpture in welded steel.
